entry.title: Drive more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – A Recommendation Guide
entry.content:
After spending almost 10 years helping customers activate and operate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, I wanted to provide a quick guide on some initiatives based on my experience that you can follow to get more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This blog will cover some of the top recommendations but is by no means a conclusive or complete list, as there are many other topics that can be added. Now, some of these recommendations may already be included in your subscription or some might not; this will be an individual customer situation, so I encourage you to contact your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner to inquire about your individual situation.

First, if you are reading this blog, it is because you have probably been operating SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some time and are looking to get more out of your subscription investment.

If you are reading this blog and you are planning to implement public cloud, I suggest you read this first.

Let me provide you with some of my highlights:

 

  • New Innovations – Find and explore new innovations using the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (SAP RASD - A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login) to analyze new innovations included in your subscription.  I have recommended this tool in previous blogs to get ready for upgrades so you can consume new innovation and maintain your system. However, in this case I want to focus on the topic of innovation only. The tool will highlight all innovations included in a release, or you can see the innovations tailored to your productive system usage. However you want to do this, I advise you to benefit from all this new innovation that was added to your system.

New Innovations - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

  • SAP Business Artificial Intelligence – The SAP RASD Tool can also support exploring the special use cases for SAP Business AI (SAP Joule, Agents, embedded AI). You can use the tool to showcase what has been added into the release. Similar to the above use case, the SAP RASD tool can showcase all the topics per release or tailor them to your productive usage for SAP Business AI.

SAP Business AI - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Another tool that can help you visualize the overall use cases for SAP Business AI is the SAP Discovery Center (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/index.html), which you can use to explore what is delivered as standard so you can use it to assess your business needs. The difference with the SAP RASD Tool is that SAP Discovery Center presents all available cases independent of release for all SAP product portfolios and can also be tailored by SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, etc.), while in the case of SAP RASD, it shows the information by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and by release (e.g., 2508).

SAP Business AI - SAP Discovery Center

I have written on the topic of foundational elements for Business AI before, so I advise you to review this blog that contains many more recommendations on this important subject: Foundational Elements for Harnessing the Power of Business AI in Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Ed.

 

  • Manage News Application – The Manage News Fiori application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers system administrators to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users through a centralized news feed. By tailoring communication to organizational needs, the application enhances visibility and keeps users informed of key system and company developments—all in a single, easily accessible location.

Manage News Application

News - My Home

 

  • Keep informed of the latest regulatory changes: If you have multi-country operations and footprint, I recommend using the SAP Regulatory Change Manager to always stay up to date with changes in regulations. More information can be found here.

SAP Regulatory Change Manager

 

  • 3 System Landscape – If you are running a two-system landscape, you might want to work with SAP so they can convert you to the latest and greatest 3 System Landscape. The 3 System Landscape comes with additional benefits that will help you drive much more business value out of your SAP investment. To learn more about this topic, I recommend this blog and video that explain the process and benefits.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - 3 System Landscape

 

  • Parallel Line: If you are on a 3-System landscape and are not using the parallel line, you are missing out. The parallel line will provide you with an additional environment you can use to run testing, training, mock-up loads, test new configuration, try the configuration localization toolkit, etc. The parallel line can be used to avoid impacts to the main line and current business operations.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Parallel Line

I have also written about this topic in detail in the past, so feel free to look at this blog with all details:  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, three-system landscape, parallel line – High Level Introduction.

 

  • 2-Tier ERP Strategy – Maybe you implemented SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some subsidiaries or maybe for your corporate business; however, the goal was, we are seeing more and more SAP customers running hybrid deployments to connect their SAP systems with either corporate headquarters running in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or looking at SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to bring new acquisitions or subsidiaries.

2-Tier ERP

The strategies are diverse and depend on your business requirements; however, SAP has many options to support you in this using our 2-tier models. I suggest you read this blog to learn more about these specific strategies: Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA.

 

  • Extending to the new SAP Business Suite Packages - In February 2025, SAP announced the new SAP Business Suite. The Business Suite serves as a transformation engine, helping customers generate rapid cycles of innovation and continuous improvement as a service. This enables organizations to deliver greater business value and achieve improved outcomes through end-to-end processes. So with the new SAP Business Suite, you have a great opportunity to complement your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with some of the current packages (e.g., SAP Strategic Procurement, SAP Core HR (which includes SuccessFactors for example), SAP CX, etc.), or potentially change your entire subscription to the new SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages to benefit from more entitlements that cover more functionality to address specific business pain points. This last point is not available yet, but is planned for 2026, so stay tuned. But a new installation and subscription can start with new SAP Business Suite Packages right away.

SAP Business Suite

This strategy could prepare you for future consumption models where you have much more capabilities at your disposal. I invite you to learn more about this topic here: Unpacking the new SAP Business Suite.

 

  • WalkMe – WalkMe can help you with the onboarding of new users (e.g., if you are bringing a new company code or new country rollout) as it helps drive user adoption using its capabilities to ease the use of the system by providing guided tours, samples, and even automations of tasks. At the moment, WalkMe provides out-of-the-box content for MyHome, Procurement Specialist, Sales Representative, and Financial Accountant, and more content will be added in the future. You can also use its current editor capabilities to create your own content and help drive user adoption and onboarding.

WalkMe & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • SAP Signavio Process Intelligence is a good option to really understand how the system is being used and try to drive enhancements based on current system usage and KPIs. Currently, SAP Signavio Process Intelligence offers two out-of-the-box processes including Order to Cash and Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) that can be used to drive inferences on these end-to-end processes. More end-to-end processes will be added in the future. However, customers can use Process Intelligence to create their own content to analyze their specific usage and drive enhancements to the overall system productivity and usage based on very concrete production data to help drive transformation of processes.

SAP Signavio Process Intelligence & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If you want to know more about SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, check this blog and example.

 

I hope this selective list of recommendations provides you some ideas for your new projects, new business rollouts, or new business requirements. Feel free to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

We still take the sequenced JIT call business in automobile industry as an example. After we confirm all the related master data are prepared, we test in system by reference the main process described in previous overview blog:

  1. Create the customer JIT Call manually by Fiori App Manage Customer JIT Calls

You specify the External JIT Call Number (This can be from customer), Customer Vehicle Number, Customer Vehicle Model and other customer information. These cover all the request information from customer.

Component Groups will be automatically determined after you added new components.

In App Monitor Customer JIT Calls, you may check all the created JIT Calls with the status showed.

  1. Following most actions related to JIT Calls can all be executed in App Manage Customer JIT Calls By Component Groups.

Select your Teams Name, appropriate functions that could be performed by this team are displayed. Click the action button to perform corresponding actions.

The first action is Create Packing Group:

After the action being successfully executed, you may check the application log by clicking the Application Log on the same screen.

The application log detail will tell you what happened to this JIT call by this action.

Now the Packing Group is created based on the package specification defined, and you will find the new created packing group in the component group information of JIT Call:

The Internal Processing Status was changed from JIT Call Created(0100) to Packing Group Allocated (0130):

Since we will supply the customer JIT request with production. Now we release the JIT call to production:

Updated status also displayed on the same screen:

Packing Group Status updated too:

After the production completed, we perform the confirmation by clicking Confirm Production:

Goods movement posted while performing the production confirmation with movement type 261 for component consumption and movement type 131 for product receiving.

  1. The we perform packing related actions here: Release to Packing, Confirm Packing, Create Handling Unit from Package Group, Create Outbound Delivery.

After the outbound delivery created, We can see the delivery number on the JIT call Component screen:

We perform picking via App Pick Outbound Delivery:

Outbound Deliveries for Goods Issue:

Material document with movement type 601 generated after goods issue posting:

  1. Then we create billing document via App Create Billing Documents.

Now we will see the status of all actions on the customer JIT Call are completed:

We have some reports for the insights of Just-In-Time Processing. You may use Demand Analysis for Customer JIT Calls to compare the Customer JIT Calls and schedule line from forecast delivery schedules.

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received → Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted → Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

hese rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 – Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 – Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP’s standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era — Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview — Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Key Design Principles

Principle Description
Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.
AI-enabledEmbedded Joule AI assistant supports planning and exception handling.
Network-readyPre-integrated with SAP Business Network for Logistics.
Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope — From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics — Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics — all running in the cloud.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit

InboundGoods receipt, putaway, inspectionReduce manual errors and waiting time.
InternalBin management, replenishmentOptimize space and movement.
OutboundPicking, packing, staging, loadingFaster fulfillment accuracy.
MobileScanning & task confirmationReal-time execution; paperless workflow.
MonitoringDashboards & alertsImprove supervisory visibility.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer’s regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels — no need for spreadsheets.

Key Fiori Apps in Warehouse Logistics

App Name Usage
Warehouse MonitorSupervisors track workload, resources, exceptions.
Execute Warehouse TasksOperators perform putaway/picking with handhelds.
Manage Inbound DeliveriesCreate, monitor, and post receipts for inbound deliveries.

Transportation Logistics — Intelligent Freight Orchestration

Transportation Logistics in LGM brings planning, tendering, execution, and freight costing into one intelligent workflow. It eliminates spreadsheet-based planning and manual RFQs by integrating real-time carrier collaboration.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
PlanningLoad building, route optimisation & consolidationCut freight costs and carbon footprint.
TenderingPeer-to-peer / broadcast to carriersAutomate carrier selection.
ExecutionFreight order tracking & event managementAchieve end-to-end visibility.
CostingFreight cost calculation & invoice reconciliationImprove financial accuracy.
AppointmentDock scheduling & time windowsReduce waiting time and idle assets.

Manage Freight RFQs App: A chemical manufacturer planning an urgent dispatch to Delhi creates an RFQ in LGM. Three carriers receive tenders instantly via BN4L; within minutes, Carrier A accepts with best price and lead time — no emails or phone calls needed.

Key Fiori Apps in Transportation Logistics

App Name Usage
Manage Freight RFQsCreate/manage carrier RFQs.
Tender Freight OrdersPublish freight offers to carriers.
Track Freight OrdersView live shipment events & status.

Network Collaboration — Connected by Design

Network Collaboration within SAP LGM links shippers and carriers digitally via the SAP Business Network for Logistics. It replaces emails and calls with structured collaboration — carrier tenders, dock appointments, shipment events, and POD uploads all happen in one network workspace.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
Carrier CollaborationTender acceptance / status updatesFaster onboarding, less manual follow-up.
Appointment SchedulingDock slot managementSmoother inbound/outbound flow.
Tracking & EventsMilestones & delay alertsPredictive visibility.
DocumentationProof of Delivery / Freight invoice sharingPaperless compliance.

Manage Carrier Collaboration App: A transport partner accepts a freight order from the shipper and uploads the signed POD once delivery is complete. The system automatically updates LGM and triggers freight invoice posting in ERP.

Key Fiori Apps in Network Collaboration

App Name Usage
Manage Carrier CollaborationDigital tender acceptance & status updates.
Schedule Dock AppointmentsDock slot coordination with carriers.
Monitor Shipment MilestonesTrack shipment events and POD status.

Unified Planning & Control — Visibility in One View

Narrative
The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

Feature Description
Unified Planning ConsoleAggregate view of all logistics plans & statuses.
Control TowerMonitors execution progress and exceptions.
KPI DashboardsVisualises service levels and throughput.
Exception HandlingGuided workflows to resolve delays and errors.

Logistics Dashboard App: A distribution manager opens the dashboard each morning to view all facilities on one screen. If a lane’s OTD drops below 95 %, he drills into that carrier and sends an RFQ for replacement service — action taken within minutes, not days.

Key Fiori Apps in Unified Planning & Control

App Name Usage
Logistics DashboardKPI overview of logistics network.
Exception Management HubCentralised issue tracking & resolution.
Dashboard for PlanningCompare planned vs actual performance.

Integration — Seamless by Default

LGM connects to SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network using standard APIs and content packages. Data flows bi-directionally for deliveries, goods movements, freight costs and invoices. This ensures a single source of truth across finance and operations.

Intelligence Layer — Joule AI for Smarter Decisions

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is built into LGM. It understands context, answers in natural language, and automates common decisions like carrier selection or route replanning.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

A planner types, “Which deliveries are at risk today?” Joule returns a list of orders facing delays and suggests rescheduling or alternate carriers based on historic performance. The planner approves in one click — no manual analysis

Business Benefits — Tangible Value for Growing Companies

Area Impact
SpeedGuided cloud deployment reduces implementation time by 50 %.
VisibilityUnified planning console gives end-to-end control.
EfficiencyAI and automation reduce manual coordination effort.
ScalabilityStart with one site or process, expand as needed.
Continuous InnovationQuarterly updates add new features without upgrades.

entry.title: Where to begin with SAP Requirements in Jira?
entry.content:
I think all of SAP project experts will agree that SAP Requirements Management is much more than an Excel file downloaded from the SAP Activate Roadmap accelerators list and filled with unstructured notes from Fit-2-Standard workshops. In practice, Requirements Management should be the bridge between business intent and tested, working functionality. And yet, this bridge often does not exist. The disconnect between what business processes should do and what finally goes live remains one of the biggest causes of rework and missed value in SAP programs.

Why managing requirements is important?

A weak requirements discipline leads later to solution scope creep, fragmented testing, and the famous “this isn’t what we expected” moment during the UAT. Well organized requirements management turns conversations into commitments - every requirement becomes traceable from the "Need" through "Realize and Test" to "Deploy". Traceability is the essence of governance in SAP Activate.

High-level business outcomes are defined during Discover and Prepare phase, while detailed functional, non-functional, and delta requirements are refined and documented during the Explore phase. They are documented against SAP Best Practice processes (for example BD9 - Sell from Stock).

Every requirement should be linked to its related Test Case and Work Package to ensure full traceability from Fit-to-Standard through Deployment. This linkage keeps it transparent, testable, and aligned with business value.

How SAP Activate Defines a Requirement

In the Requirements-to-Deploy (R2D) framework, a requirement is a single, testable statement describing the system behavior or capability needed to fulfill a business need.
Each requirement should be:
1) Atomic – one clear need, not a bundle of ideas.
2) Unambiguous – can be interpreted only in one way.
3) Traceable – linked to a Process, Scope Item and Work Package (deliverable).
4) Testable – verifiable through objective criteria.

A requirement is not a meeting note like ‘Need better reports’; it states precisely what the system must do. It defines what the system must achieve but not yet how to implement it.

When written in a standardized way, requirements become the shared language between Business and IT - the foundation for alignment, testing, and auditability.

 Practically in Jira

Ok, so if it is now clear what a requirement is and how it should be defined, the next question becomes where to manage all this effectively. That’s where Jira - when properly configured - becomes a practical backbone for collecting, tracking, and approving SAP requirements.

In Jira, requirements can be managed as custom Work Item types aligned with SAP Activate governance standards.

  1. Create a dedicated work item type called Requirement with a distinct icon.

  2. Configure essential fields and workflow statuses (e.g., Draft → To Be Approved → Approved → In Realization → Completed).

  3. Link each requirement to its Scope item, ensuring full traceability.

Once configured, you can collect requirements directly in Jira during your Fit-To-Standard workshops.

SAP native tools

While SAP Cloud ALM and Solution Manager’s Focused Build provide strong governance for requirement-to-deploy processes, many organizations still complement them with Jira to enable broader Agile methods delivery, integrate non-SAP workstreams, and leverage its native links with Confluence and Test automation tools. Also, there are a few integration tools available that allow for data exchange between Jira and SAP.

Your Goal

In any SAP project, your goal is to ensure that every piece of delivered and tested functionality traces back to at least one well-written requirement. However, the discipline lies not in the tool itself but in the governance structure and consistency with which it’s used.

If you have found this article informative, please leave me a Kudo on top of this page.
This will encourage me to write more articles in SAP Community. Thank you!

About author

Bogdan Górka works as Atlassian Solution Architect and SAP Project Governance Consultant.
Creator of R2D ALM for Jira, independent Atlassian consultant, and founder of PMBG.EU.

entry.title: How to turn SAP workshop notes into clear and testable Requirements
entry.content:
During SAP Activate’s Explore phase and the Fit-to-Standard workshops, consultants capture dozens of “requirements,” each meant to articulate a specific business need. Without clear formulation standards, a few weeks later no one is quite sure what the original request actually meant. This undermines the workshop’s primary goal: validating solution fit.

The real pain - inconsistency

In SAP programs, requirements that are vague or inconsistently written become a main source of unnecessarily lost effort. When two workstreams describe the same business need in different words, duplication multiply which may lead to unnecessary testing of the same functionality or cause change requests.

For example, when a requirement says “system should support automatic approval” no one will know what support actually meant when they discussed it during a workshop. You cannot test such a requirement later.

Ambiguity has measurable cost

Each unclear requirement multiplies into unnecessary discussions, rework, and test defects. Misunderstandings accumulate silently until they become visible during the first cycle of testing, when the system finally reveals whether the requirement was truly met.

The true risk of Requirements Management is not the absence of requirements documentation, but the lack of consistency in how requirements are formulated.

Not having the requirement formulation standards, which are recommended by SAP Activate, is one of the major sources of rework and wasted effort. When requirements are written in different formats and tones, they cannot be easily classified, compared, or reused.

Why clear formulation matters

SAP Activate’s agile approach is built on the idea that requirements evolve. But they must be clear right from the start as the backlog entry, so that they can be reviewed, classified, and approved later. Clarity does not mean rigidity. It means writing requirements so they can be discussed, prioritized, tested, and traced - even as they may change later.

 A well formulated requirement contains four elements in one short sentence:

Who – the role that needs the functionality
When – the situation or trigger
What – the action or system behavior
Why – the intended business benefit

When these four parts are present, the requirement becomes verifiable. It can be confirmed during testing and explained during audit reviews. More importantly, it can be reused across teams and releases because it is self-contained and unambiguous.

The right format for SAP projects

SAP’s Agile method proposes the familiar User Story format: “As a [role], I want [feature], so that [business value].” In practice, this structure is often too generic for configuration and testing.

A better pattern for SAP requirements adds context and system behavior:

As [Role], when [Condition], the system will [Action] on [Object] so that [Benefit].

This sentence looks simple, but it solves three common problems:

1) It describes the trigger (when), which links to a real process step.
2) It defines the system reaction (will [Action]), which makes the behavior testable.
3) It keeps the business benefit explicit, which ties it back to value and approval.

This version includes all four elements: who, when, what, and why.
Anyone reading it should understands both the intent and the expected outcome.

Adding a “How to Demo” section

A practical way to make requirements even clearer is to include a short “How to Demo” note directly under the description. This is not a full test case but rather a quick outline of how someone would prove that the requirement works. This serves as a draft for formal test cases and ensures that requirements can be verified during Activate’s test preparation phase.

This small “How to demo” section acts as an early test-case draft. It helps reviewers visualize expected behavior and gives testers a ready starting point for building the formal Test Case later. In larger projects, these demo notes become a lightweight bridge between requirement authoring and structured testing, keeping intent, behavior, and verification tightly connected.

Finding the right level of detail

A well-written requirement should guide the Realize phase. Too much detail turns it into a mini-functional specification; too little makes it meaningless. The right level of abstraction sits between business intention and technical configuration.

When many team members are involved in requirements formulation, duplication can easily occur. Similar needs appear in different modules, often under different wording. To prevent this, each requirement should reference its related SAP Best Practice Process represented by an approved Scope Item. This simple linking helps identify overlaps early and supports reuse across workstreams.

From quick notes to refined requirements

In line with SAP Activate’s iterative principle, requirements may first be recorded in simple terms and refined later during backlog reviews and work package definition. What matters most in that moment is to capture the intent in a simplified form and then refine it later.

For example:
“Add a process step for automatic credit check approval before delivery creation.” → GAP

Such a note still has value. During later review, typically when preparing the related Work Package, the requirement can be reformulated to the full standard:

As a Sales Manager, when a sales order is saved and the customer exceeds the credit limit, the system will block delivery creation on the delivery document so that only approved orders can ship.

This two-step approach keeps workshops efficient while ensuring that every requirement ultimately meets the agreed structure before review, approval, and test preparation.

How to make this standard work in Jira?

Formulation discipline is easier to maintain when supported by a tool.
In Jira, you can create an automation rule that pre-populates the Description field of each new Requirement with a Activate-style structured template.

In the template, you can use a table to make the content easier to follow. Each author then only needs to fill in the blanks. This keeps every requirement standardized.

For simplicity, below the requirement you can add a simple list with the ‘How to demo’ steps.

Why it’s worth the effort?

A requirement is not a transcript of a workshop discussion. It is a helpful SAP governance standard that supports the SAP delivery lifecycle.

Teams that adopt this standardization rule quickly notice tangible benefits:
-> Requirements become easier to review and approve.
-> Test cases can be linked directly and generated faster.
-> Cross-team understanding improves, because every sentence follows the same logic.

Formulation discipline may feel like a big effort, but it pays back throughout the project lifecycle. Clear requirements accelerate testing, improve governance, and reduce rework.

entry.title: How to build clarity in SAP Projects with Jira
entry.content:
Is it your day in SAP project life?

Your SAP project is in the middle of Fit-to-Standard analysis, your Requirements Backlog grows quickly, requirements are flowing in from all teams, but it’s impossible to see what matters most or what type of work is hiding behind the summary and description.

If that sounds familiar, your project might be missing the structured requirement classification discipline recommended by SAP Activate. Without this approach, the requirements backlog turns into a flat list, where priorities will be hard to assign and some of the expected outcomes will not be properly documented.

With structured classification, it becomes clear what type of outcomes we’re delivering and what kind of documentation and work is actually required. It enables credible estimation, release wave planning, and test coverage without the need to re-explain the project every week.

What is Requirement Classification?

Classification provides a structured way to label requirements so they can be grouped, prioritized, tracked, and reported consistently across both functional and technical workstreams.
Together with formulation standards, it keeps your requirements backlog clean and actionable for delivery and status reporting.

Every requirement should be labeled along two dimensions:

1️) Level - hierarchy: shows where the requirement sits in the project - higher strategic level or lower detailed level.
2️) Type - nature of work: signals what kind of effort is needed to deliver it.

The Dual Classification Model — Levels & Types

Levels hierarchy - reflects the “zoom” level:
-> L1 – High-Level Business Requirement: The “why” - what business value or capability must be achieved.
-> L2 – Process-Level Requirement: The “what” - process activities or steps that bring the business outcome to life.
-> L3 – Functional Requirement: The “how” - concrete system behaviors, validations, or interactions that enable the process step. At this level, SAP Activate recommends requirements be formulated so they are traceable and testable.

Types - nature of work - reflects the solution pathway:
-> FIT: Standard SAP functionality meets the need as is; adopt standard SAP.
-> GAP: Missing functionality requiring additional configuration or enhancement.
-> EXT (Extension / WRICEF): Technical work — interfaces, reports, conversions, enhancements, forms.
-> NFR (Non-Functional Requirement): Qualities such as performance, security, compliance, or usability.

Combine both dimensions and you’ll see your full solution scope - how much fits standard SAP, which areas need only configuration, and where technical extensions or non-functional demands will influence delivery. This will help later with accurate effort estimation and release governance.

From Discover to Explore: how requirements detail changes

Discover Phase:
Requirements are collected as high-level outcomes or business goals mapped to solution scope. They are articulated as value drivers and not yet detailed as process or system requirements.
Prepare Phase:
Refined and agreed high level requirements are turned into scope statements and acceptance criteria. They become part of the project charter, forming the project baseline.
Explore Phase:
Time to dive in. Now, during the Fit-to-Standard workshops, the team validates which SAP Best Practices satisfy business needs (FIT), pinpoint deltas (GAP, EXT/WRICEF, NFR), and detail process-level or functional requirements for each business activity. The goal is not to restate strategic goals but to clarify how each is realized in process terms.

Requirements refinement example

Here is a quick example to demonstrate how the level of details changes between requirement levels. These changes are the result of iterations.

High Level (L1):
“Ensure that customer credit exposure is controlled during the order-to-cash process to minimize financial risk and enforce company credit policy.”
Process Level (L2):
“Add a process step to validate customer credit before order confirmation, ensuring that orders exceeding credit limits are identified and stopped before delivery or invoicing.”
Functional Level (L3):
“As a Sales Representative when a Sales Order is saved for a customer whose credit exposure exceeds their credit limit the system will automatically block the Sales Order and display a message indicating the credit limit breach so that financially non-compliant orders are prevented from further processing and company credit policy is enforced.”
Depending on SAP coverage, requirement form this example could be a GAP (needs configuration) or an EXT (custom validation).

When a Level 3 requirement is formulated using an agreed template and properly classified, it becomes much easier to estimate the required effort and remains traceable from the very beginning all the way through deployment.

What about Non-Functional Requirements?

It may seem counterintuitive, but SAP methodologies - including Activate and Focused Build - classify most Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) at the same (functional) level as detailed system requirements. While their name suggests they are “non-functional,” they describe qualities that apply to specific system functions, such as performance, security, or usability. In practice, they sit at the same level of detail as functional requirements, because they can be specified, tested, and verified against system behavior.

For example:

“The system shall process 10 000 purchase order lines within 60 seconds under normal load conditions.”
“User data shall be stored only within EU-based data centers.”

 Bringing classification to practice in Jira

The flexibility of Jira allows you to capture more than just a requirement’s name and description. You can also collect structured metadata for governance and reporting. You are not limited in customizations like in SAP native tools.

Possible Jira configuration:

  • Add custom fields to record key attributes such as Requirement Level (High-Level, Process-Level, Functional) and Requirement Type (FIT, GAP, EXT, NFR, etc.).

  • Configure these fields as drop-down lists so that users must select a defined value, ensuring consistent classification across all teams.

Standardized metadata enables filtering, reporting, and building reporting dashboards by type, level, or workstream, giving full transparency into project and solution scope composition.

Even that simple setup unlocks powerful reporting in Jira: dashboards showing % FIT coverage, distribution of GAPs and WRICEFs, or NFR readiness by release. Your backlog becomes a live dashboard, not a static list in Excel.

 

What’s in it for you?

Just like requirement formulation standard discussed on SAP Community here, clarity is also about bringing structure and governance to Requirements Management. When every requirement has its place and type, governance stops being a reporting exercise and becomes a shared language. Classification is not overhead or project administration - it is the structure that keeps delivery, design, and testing aligned, supports compliance, and maintains clear documentation from the first workshop to go-live.

And the question
If I opened your requirements tracker today (I hope it is Jira) and picked five random requirements, would I instantly see what each one means, what type of work it implies, and where it fits in your process? If not, you know now what to do.

entry.title: Test Data Refresh: Enhancing test tenant quality
entry.content:
We have seen how data migration is supported during 3SL conversion in our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community blog, we have also seen how Test Data Conversion (TDC) plays a vital role in accelerating the test tenant readiness with valid depersonalised test data and system configurations from Previous quality tenant in Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community blog.  

Building on that foundation, this blog focuses on the next topic, Test Data Refresh (TDR) in the 3SL post conversion journey. TDR is a strategic service offered by SAP to ensure the availability of high quality, production like test data in the test tenant for all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers. Let’s understand the purpose, value, and prerequisites of TDR, and realise how it enhances ongoing quality assurance and supports efficient testing environment. 

 

 TDR: Ongoing quality assurance: 

The TDR service is a subscription-based service with the flexibility of multi-use service designed to provide S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers with accurate, production-like data in their test tenant. It ensures that the test tenant reflects the latest application data from the production tenant, enabling realistic and effective testing scenarios.   

 

TDR offers a powerful solution for transferring production like data from the production tenant to the test tenant with the option of depersonalisation feature. It supports the migration of:  

  • Master Data  
  • Transactional Data  

 

TDR Pre-requisites:  

To have a smooth and flawless data transfer during the TDR implementation, the following key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level:  

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants:  All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration to eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow.  
  2. System Configuration Maintenance: A well-maintained System configuration is essential for system stability there by reduces integration friction.   
  3. Content Version Alignment: All tenants should be in the same content version release to overcome errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.   
  4. Extension Readiness: Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates by making use of The Handle Your Extensions application.  
  5. Clean Production Transport Queue: Make sure that there are no open transports in the development queue to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts.  

Note:  The TDR team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants, thereby simplifying the process and ensuring the system readiness for TDR onboarding.  

 

TDR Process Overview: 

Customers can request TDR service any time during the year based on the Test Data Refresh calendar (kindly refer to the reference link section for the TDR calendar link).  

During the TDR process, the target (Test) tenant application data will be cleared, followed by a full refresh of application data from source (Production) tenant. This ensures the latest high quality and accurate test data availability in the testing tenant to facilitate efficient testing of the developments before moving to production tenant.  

Note: During TDR process, data in target tenant such as system configurations, user data and authorization data will be retained as it is. 

 To ensure data privacy, TDR service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the data transfer process.  

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. Kindly refer to SAP help page to explore depersonalization in detail.  

 

Conclusion:  

In this Blog, we’ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDR. We've also seen how TDR enhances the quality of test data and enriching the test environment and supports a smoother transition to the new test tenant in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDR, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant.

entry.title: The Importance of Primary Finance Settings in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
• This blog is based on version CE2508.
  • The screenshots shown come from an internal SAP test system.

This blog is designed for consultants and customers who are just beginning their journey with SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition). Understanding and correctly configuring the Primary Finance Settings is one of the most critical early steps in an implementation project.

 

Why Primary Finance Settings Matter?

At the start of any SAP Cloud ERP implementation, defining the Primary Finance Settings is a fundamental activity. These settings include:

  • Fiscal Year Variant

  • Group Currency

  • Ledgers and Accounting Principles

These initial configurations form the financial backbone of your system. They directly influence all subsequent financial postings, ledgers, and company codes across your organization. Since they are deeply embedded in the system structure, they must be carefully planned and chosen — because once saved, they cannot be changed.

 

What are the Primary Finance Settings?
The “Specify Primary Finance Settings” activity is a one-time configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC).

Here, you define two crucial values:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Determines how your financial year is divided (e.g., calendar or non-calendar year).

  • Group Currency: Ensures consistent and comparable financial reporting across your global entities.

Once these values are saved, they cannot be changed.

The system even displays a clear message:
“Be aware that this is a one-time decision which cannot be changed.” This highlights just how significant these settings are for your overall ERP landscape.

 

How can I configure the Primary Finance Settings?

Step 1: Selecting Ledgers and Accounting Principles

The number and type of ledgers are defined during the initial scoping phase, and — just like the other finance settings — cannot be modified later.

During the Define Scope activity, you’ll select the scope items that determine which ledgers are activated:

  • J58 – Activates the Leading Ledger (0L), assigned to the local GAAP at company code level.

  • 1GA – Activates Ledger 2L, corresponding to IFRS accounting principles.

  • 2VA – Activates Ledger 3L, corresponding to US GAAP accounting principles.

Important:
If you choose to work only with one ledger (0L), IFRS and US GAAP principles and their related content will not be available.

For multi-ledger setups, ensure each ledger is assigned to the correct accounting principle. In this blog, I provided detailed guidance: SAP Recommendation: Assignment of Corporate Accounting Principle to Ledger. 

 

Step 2: Defining the Fiscal Year Variant and Group Currency
Within the Specify Primary Finance Settings activity, you select:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Defines your company’s financial reporting structure — for instance, whether your fiscal year aligns with the calendar year or follows a custom pattern.

  • Group Currency: A key value that drives consistent financial consolidation and reporting across all entities and ledgers.

 

 

Where Do These Settings Apply?

The Fiscal Year Variant selected during setup is applied to the Leading Ledger and cannot be changed later.

  • Non-leading Ledgers will inherit this setting, but can be adjusted if necessary.

For a full list of supported fiscal year variants, please refer to the SAP Road Map Viewer> SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) > Explore phase >  accelerator file “Supported Fiscal Year Variant.xlsx”

The Group Currency applies to all ledgers and company codes in the system.

 

What If You Need to Modify These Settings?

If you realize that your initial configuration was incorrect or needs to be changed, the only option is to request a System Reprovisioning.

However, be aware:

This process can delay your project timeline by more than three weeks.

Please find more details:

  • 3401017 - FAQs about S/4HANA Public Cloud System Reprovisioning
  • Getting started with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Project - Dodging the System Re-Provisioning Bullets 

To conclude:

The Primary Finance Settings define the financial core of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition system.  Because these settings are permanent, always validate your selections carefully before saving. Taking the time to get them right up front will save time on rework and delays later.

 

SAP Help Portal Links:

  • Setting Your Group Currency 
  • Fiscal Year and Fiscal Year Variant 
  • Ledger

Stay tuned for more tips and insights!

entry.title: Configurer un Flux d'Approbation Flexible pour le Bon de Commande (SAP S/4HANA Cloud)
entry.content:
📘 Guide Complet : Configurer un Flux d'Approbation Flexible pour le Bon de Commande (SAP S/4HANA Cloud)

Ce guide est conçu pour tous les types d'utilisateurs, des utilisateurs finaux ("Dummies") aux consultants et utilisateurs clés. Nous allons transformer une procédure technique  en un processus métier complet de bout en bout, incluant les concepts, la configuration détaillée, et un plan de test pratique.

Ce guide est basé sur la version SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 23081.

  • 1. 💡 Concepts : Qu'est-ce que le Workflow Flexible ? (Pour les "Nuls" et Utilisateurs Finaux)

Avant de configurer, comprenons-le "pourquoi" et le "comment".

Qu'est-ce que c'est ?

Le Workflow Flexible est la méthode moderne de SAP S/4HANA pour gérer les processus d'approbation. Voyez-le comme un "robot" de routage intelligent pour vos documents.

  • Avant (L'ancienne méthode) : Les règles d'approbation (stratégies de lancement) étaient rigides, complexes et nécessitaient souvent un expert technique (un développeur) pour être modifiées.
  • Maintenant (Le Workflow Flexible) : Les règles sont définies par les utilisateurs clés (Key Users) directement dans une application Fiori. C'est visuel, adaptable et ne nécessite aucun code.

Pourquoi l'utiliser ?

  • Flexibilité : Vous pouvez changer les règles (ex: "Approbation requise si > 1000 EUR" au lieu de 500 EUR) en quelques clics.
  • Mobilité : Les approbateurs reçoivent les tâches dans leur application My Inbox et peuvent approuver depuis leur ordinateur ou leur téléphone.
  • Traçabilité : Vous voyez exactement qui doit approuver, qui a approuvé, et à quelle heure.

Le Processus de Bout en Bout (Exemple simple)

  1. Création : Un acheteur crée une commande d'achat (PO) de 600 EUR.
  2. Déclenchement : Le système vérifie les règles. Il voit que 600 EUR est supérieur à la limite de 500 EUR que nous avons définie.
  3. Approbation : Le système bloque la PO et envoie automatiquement une tâche d'approbation au manager (ex: dans l'application My Inbox).
  4. Action : Le manager ouvre la tâche, vérifie la PO, et clique sur "Approuver".
  5. Libération : Le système libère automatiquement la PO. Elle est maintenant officielle et peut être envoyée au fournisseur.
  • 2. 🛠️ Guide de Configuration (Pour les Utilisateurs Clés et Consultants)

Cette section détaille le "comment" construire le processus, en suivant précisément la procédure de vos documents.

  1. Prérequis
  • Vous devez être connecté avec le rôle : Configuration Expert - Business Process Configuration3.
  • Le workflow flexible doit déjà être activé pour le type de document d'achat (ex: NB) dans votre système. C'est une étape de configuration de base (scoping).
  1. Procédure de Configuration (Étape par Étape)

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Security: Integrating Microsoft Sentinel
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now integrated with Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP 

This blog was co-authored with Martin Pankraz (SAP Security PM, Microsoft) 

In the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, most of the security tasks are handled by the cloud service provider – SAP in this case. However, in order to obtain a comprehensive picture of your security posture and for comprehensive threat detection, certain information from the application is also needed. For this, SAP provides APIs for security relevant data - such as the Security Audit Log when we’re speaking about event driven data, but also more static APIs to establish a security dashboard are provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  

Providing this information, however, is – quite literally – only half of the story. In order to make sense of this information, the receiving solution needs to make sense of the data provided, combine it with relevant data from other systems within the landscape and correlate information with each other. This solution also needs to understand the application that provides the information, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in this case.  

This is why we’re especially thrilled to announce the Microsoft Sentinel for SAP integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - a cloud-native integration that brings real-time threat detection, investigation, and response to your SAP environment.

Why This Matters  

With Microsoft Sentinel as the receiving end of the security relevant APIs that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides, customers receive a lightweight, scalable, compliant, and AI ready approach to integrate SAP telemetry into their enterprise security operations. 

Our integration delivers exactly that: 

  • Agentless deployment for faster onboarding. 
  • Unified security operations across SAP and non-SAP systems. 
  • Compliance-ready log retention at a fraction of traditional costs. 

What This Release Offers 

  1. 1. AI enabled unified Security Operations 
  • Correlate SAP Cloud events with enterprise telemetry in Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP and Microsoft Defender XDR ready for Microsoft Security Copilot. 
  • Use prebuilt analytics rules, workbooks, and SOAR playbooks to detect and respond to threats like:  
  • Privilege escalations 
  • Unauthorized configuration changes 
  • Suspicious financial transactions 
  1. 2. Compliance-Ready Log Retention 
  • Store SAP logs cost-efficient in Microsoft Sentinel Data Lake for up to 12 years. 
  • Support threat hunting involving SAP on the Sentinel Data lake through KQL jobs. 

Key Benefits 

  • Faster Deployment: Go live in hours, not weeks. 
  • Future-Proof: Built on SAP’s strategic integration approach using APIs. 
  • Security at Scale: Detect and respond to threats across your entire SAP landscape. 

How It Works 

  1. Deploy the Microsoft Sentinel integration package in SAP Integration Suite. 
  2. Configure your Microsoft Sentinel workspace to start ingesting SAP logs. 
  3. Activate prebuilt content for instant visibility and protection. SAP S/4HANA Cloud → SAP Integration Suite → Microsoft Sentinel 

What’s Next 

  • General Availability after the current preview phase. 
  • Upcoming enhancements: Expansion of protection scope to additional communication scenarios provided by SAP. 

Getting Started 

Activate SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Microsoft Sentinel Integration | Azure portal from the Sentinel Content Hub. Provide your connection details for communication scenario 750 and you are good to go. 

Once deployed, we recommend to check AryaG’s series giving details on how to move to production 

Final Words 

#Kudos to the amazing engineering teams on both sides and our incredible community contributors! 

That's a wrap. Remember: bringing SAP under the protection of your central SIEM isn't just a checkbox - it's essential for comprehensive security and compliance across your entire IT estate. 

Cheers, Patrick & Martin

entry.title: Expiring Price Handling Powered by Joule
entry.content:
The Joule capability "Expiring Price Handling" has been released in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3. This blog introduces this feature in detail, so that you can interact with Joule smoothly and manage expiring prices efficiently. 

 

Overview

You can ask Joule to fetch prices (stored as condition records for pricing in sales in the system) that will expire soon. For expiring prices, Joule can help renew them by extending their validity periods and adjusting the condition amounts or ratios according to your requirements. After you confirm to extend the expiring prices, a price renewal background job will be created. You can also check the progress and result of the price renewal job via Joule.

Figure 1

Please check out the following help document and demo for a glimpse.

    • Help Document: Renew Expiring Prices
    • Demo: Renew Product Prices with Joule

 

Feature in Details

 

Definition of "Expiring Price"

Before using this feature, it's important to understand what qualifies as an "Expiring Price". Joule retrieves prices that expire between the current date and the given date (including both dates) without a successor record. Only records without a successor are considered "Expiring".

  • Case 1 and 2: Prices without a successor --> considered "expiring". 
  • Case 3: Even if its Valid-To date falls between the current date and the given date, it has a successor with a continuous validity period starting right after its Valid-To date --> not considered "expiring".
  • Case 4: Already expired prices --> not considered "expiring".

Figure 2

Note that, this feature only retrieves/renews the prices approaching expiration (meaning still valid for the time being), but cannot fetch/renew the prices which are already expired (Case 4 above).

 

How Are Expiring Prices Renewed?

Instead of updating the original Valid-To date of the expiring price, Joule creates a new continuous validity period for the expiring price (with Valid-From date set to the date one day after the Valid-To date of the expiring price). Optionally, the new validity period could have a new condition amount/ratio. The purpose of this is to keep the existing "Expiring Price" unchanged, but create its successor only.

Do take note that, the new validity being created could possibly overlap with the existing validity that lies in future, such as the Case 2 above. Assume that the gap between the expiring price and its future validity is 9 months long. If we extend the validity period of the expiring price by 1 year, the new validity and existing future validity will overlap for 3 months. In this case, the new validity will overwrite the existing validity during the overlapped period.

 

Always Start from "Show Expiring Prices"

You can activate the "Expiring Price Handling" feature by talking to Joule with phrases like below:

  • "Show me prices for sales organization 1710 that expire before December 31, 2025."
  • "List the prices with condition type PPR0 that are expiring before Dec 31, 2025."
  • "Are there any prices for condition type PPR0 and sales organization 1010 expiring before December 31, 2025?"

Even if you ask Joule to extend the expiring price directly, you will be redirected to show expiring prices, because the extension/renewal could only be performed on the expiring prices already listed in Joule.

Figure 3

Expiration date is a mandatory for querying expiring prices. If the date is not given, Joule will prompt you to provide one, so that it can proceed to search for the expiring prices.

Figure 4

For best results, include at least one of the following filters in your query. Currently, these are the only fields supported as the filter.

  • Condition type
  • Sales organization
  • Distribution channel
  • Product
  • Customer
  • Customer project ID
 
Expiration Urgency Level

The expiring prices will be listed and sorted by urgency:

  • Red:  ≤30 days left before expiration
  • Orange:  31~60 days left before expiration
  • Green:  >60 days left before expiration

Figure 5

 

Dynamic Grouping

At the time this blog is being written, Joule can display up to 30 prices per message. If more than 30 expiring prices are found, they will be grouped dynamically,  for example:

  • By condition type + sales org. + urgency level.
  • By condition type + urgency level.
  • By urgency level only.

This ensures the total number of groups is kept ≤30.

Figure 6

 

Check Price Renewal Job Log

After clicking "Confirm" to extend prices, a mass creation job will be created in the background to create the new validity periods. You can check progress and result of the renewal job by clicking the "Check Progress" button. The job result is summarized in a card format. You can click "Open in App" to navigate to the "Manage Prices - Sales" app to check the details of the job.

Figure 7

Alternatively, you can also go to "Manage Prices - Sales" app --> click "Monitor Imports and Jobs" at the upper-right corner. --> switch to "Scheduled Jobs" tab. All the previously created jobs are listed, including the mass creation job created from "Manage Prices - Sales" app. Note that the price renewal jobs created via Joule are always named "Price Renewal xxxxxxxxxxxxxx".

Figure 8

 

Limitations

Instability of Resolving Expiration Date

If you ask Joule to show the prices expiring in N months/days, Joule may occasionally resolve the expiration date incorrectly. This can lead to an inaccurate or empty results. This is because the current LLMs do not inherently have awareness of real-time information.

Thus, we recommend providing specific dates to Joule, such as "Show me prices that are going to expire before 31 Dec, 2025" or "List prices due to expire on 31/03/2026".

 

Short Request Timeout

There's a short request timeout (only 15 seconds) imposed by Joule on any API call to backend. If you don't provide any filter criteria, you may encounter a timeout.

Figure 9

Therefore, always include at least one of the supported filters while asking Joule to show the expiring prices.
